subject: CBS Evening News with Katie Couric E-Mail Alert
body:

  The Early Show | CBS Evening News | 48 Hours
    | 60 Minutes | The Saturday Early Show | CBS Sunday
    Morning | Face The
    Nation 















Hi everyone,
 
This May Day was a day of protest for U.S.
  immigrants. Tens of thousands of demonstrators in cities from Los Angeles to New
    York demanded more of the nation’s estimated
  12 million illegal immigrants be granted legalization. Bill Whitaker will
  have more on the protests. Sandra Hughes will report on how the deportation
  of illegal immigrants has divided families, with children sometimes left
  behind to fend for themselves.
 
In Cuba
  today, there was a great deal of talk that Fidel Castro would reappear at
  that country’s main May Day parade. But as hundreds of thousands of
  Cubans marched through the streets, there was no sign of Castro. Our chief
  foreign correspondent Lara Logan is there and will report on what that could
  mean.
 
Even before Congress approved a spending bill
  calling for the withdrawal of troops from Iraq, President Bush threatened a
  veto. Jim Axelrod will have the very latest on what happened today when the
  president got the bill and what’s in store in the days ahead.
 
Continuing our series, “Caught in the
  Web,” Daniel Sieberg will take a look at the growing obsession with
  Internet pornography, and how viewing it can be addictive. He’ll talk
  to one family that overcame an addiction – and also look at an
  innovative way to confront the problem.
 
Twenty Texas teenagers who died from a cocktail of
  crushed nighttime pain relievers and black-tar heroin seemed to know they
  were doing something illegal, but didn’t seem to realize it was also highly
  addictive and could be deadly. Kelly Cobiella will report on the schoolyard
  high called “cheese.”
 
It is spring fashion season in Tehran, but with the hardliners in power
  the fashion police are cracking down on non-Islamic styles more than ever.
  Elizabeth Palmer is there and talks to several Iranian women.
 
I hope you’ll join us.
 




Katie Couric
CouricandCo@cbs.com
